title: Georgia Harris.  Tape 2; side 1.  March 19, 1980.  Rock Hill, SC.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I remember, ah, we’d always have a big picnic, and, ah, John Brown used to live way up the river.  Sometimes he’d have it at his house, you know.  He was terrible to, ah—he loved to have picnics around where he was anyway sometimes.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I remember going way up the river one time to a picnic up there, up the river, where he lived up the river, and we had a good time.  They’d clean off a great big place, you know.  I think they had a ball game.  They used to have a picnic, then they’d have a ball game.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: The white boys from the outside would come in and play the Indians, and they’d have a big time!  They’d play that morning, and play another game in the afternoon.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And they would do this at John Brown’s house?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Sometimes, uh huh.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He liked to party?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, he loved a party.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So he had a good side, too?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah!  He was good.  If you knew John Brown, you’d love to talk with him!  He was a great talker.  Yeah, he was a great talker.  You would have enjoyed talking with him.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I can imagine!  He was probably—was he a lot like Roy?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Some, uh huh.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Least that was my impression.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  Until he got mad.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, did he have a temper, too?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh my, I didn’t know that.  I guess everybody’s got a temper.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, everybody has a—but we’d have a good time at a picnic!  And we’d have an all-day thing, you know?  Take it in for the whole day.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Fish?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And soup.  And all the fried chicken, cakes and pies, you know—everything that people would just cook.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Would they ever have Indian dances at that time?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, not that I know of.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: When would they do that?  Only for tourists, or—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I guess.  Because I don’t remember any Indian dances.  Only what Chief Blue, you know, worked up around here.  That’s the onliest one I know of with Indian dances.  But, ah, I remember when they used to have square dances; we used to have square dances.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Where would they have those?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: In the houses.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, really?  Well tell me about that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, they’d open up their houses—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, whoever would.  They’d have one here one night—if somebody would say, “Well, you can come to my house the next time.  We’ll have one.”  And that’s the way they have the square dances.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh.  And who would do the calling?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Different ones that they know.  Who knew how to call.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Like who?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Let’s see.  Who used to do the calling?  I’ve forgotten.  Irvin Gordon used to call some.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Is that right?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I think Early Brown called some.  Let’s see, who else?  There was somebody who was real good about calling I used to love.  When I was growing up, I used to go to square dances; we used to have them when I was growing up.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: For heaven’s sakes!  And where did they get the music?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They had one old colored fellow, and he’d pick the banjo, and they’d pass the hat to get the money to give him, to pay him.  And that was the onliest way they paid him.  Oh, he’d come—he enjoyed it!  He’d get the biggest kick out of it, I think.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He was a good old colored fellow, and he ain’t been long dead either.  I think he just died here a couple—his name was Charlie Crawford.  I never will forget him!  But he would come certain places, and he’d play for us to dance.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So if they were going to have a dance, they’d just go and get Charlie Crawford?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  They’d let him know ahead of time if they were going to have a dance.  If they were going to have one tonight, and they’d have one the next Saturday night, and they’d usually do it.  It wasn’t on Sundays now; they had it on Saturdays until 12 o’clock.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Right.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But I never will forget--!  I told you about Davis Ayers; he was an old fellow.  And after his wife died, he was terrible to want to go to a dance!  He always wanted to dance with the young girls!  [All] of us would run, because if he got near you and you didn’t have a partner, he’d ask all the girls!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And all of us knew that. We’d have a partner if we could, but, ah, but our parents always told us not to mistreat him. We were always taught if he asked us to dance with him, you know. We hated to dance with him because he was so old, and he’d stand right in the middle of the floor.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he wouldn’t hardly go around, but he’d pull on you, swing you! Swing you, you know, almost, you’d almost have to fight, you know, to get around with him.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He always liked to dance.  But we wouldn’t hurt his feelings, you know?  But, ah, my husband said, he said one night Davis was there, and somebody called time, and he said “I’ll tell you what.”  And I think he was the one that had the watch.  And they said, “Ah, let’s set the watch back!”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he went and set it back.  And my husband told me after we got married, he said, “You know, that man set the watch back.”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did he really?  He liked it that much?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He was that way.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What were the—do you remember any of the songs they used to play on that banjo?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, I don’t.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It was all bluegrass?  It was all country?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: All country music?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: All country music.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And would you have something to eat?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I think somebody brought something.  Brought something to sell around a place.  Like that, sometimes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well how many people would crowd into a house like that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, gosh, we used to have, oh, about a houseful!  Everybody went, you know.  We didn’t have no outlet to go out and go nowhere.  We, we just made—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You made your own fun?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  Everybody would go; everybody would take part.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Everyone on the reservation?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, all of them that liked to do them things would, sure.  A lot of them didn’t do anything.  Just watched some of us, just sat around and watched and enjoyed that.  Everybody’d have a good time and go home.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But it was all square dancing?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Square dancing.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: No lindy?  Fox trot?  None of that?  It was all square dances?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: All square dances.  Now, if anybody knew it they might get and dance a lindy, but—I used to be able to dance a little bit then.  I used to fox trot and two-step and go over that waltz, too.  But, I don’t know.  I liked that when I was at school, though.  But I could do all of that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What else would they do for recreation?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That was the biggest thing, I guess, they did, I guess—have square dances.  And ball games on Saturday, you know.  Through the summer time.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And then the picnics.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And picnics.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How about the movies?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Nobody went to the movies very much, just once in a great while.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Tell me about when you went to the movies the first time.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Really I don’t know when I went to the movies for the first time.  I don’t. But, you know, I went before the talking movies ever came on.  Silent movies.  But I don’t know, I guess I was a kid, a pretty good size, before I got to a movie.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But you would have to come into Rock Hill?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Uh huh.  We went to the movies sometimes.  I never was a moviegoer until after I got, until after I was married and took my grandkids to a movie.  Used to, all the kids, ah, my kids, you know, a lot of children’s movies would come to town, and, ah, my oldest son, his kids wanted to go to the movies.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And they’d berate me into going.  I never did go with them and stay with them because they never would have no patience!  I used to take them—they talk about it now; Billy talks about it.  “Remember?  I took you to see such-and-such a story, I believe.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That Old Yeller.  Do you remember that I took them to?”  And they said, “Yeah, Grandma, we remember that.”  And I went to the movies, mostly I guess I went to the movies more with Floyd than I did with my husband.  My husband never did care for movies.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He just never did care nothing about them, so we never did fool with movies.  But Floyd, when he was growing up, he would want me to go with him to the show.  And I went.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How about the fair?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well used to be, everybody went to the fair!  We’d go to the fairs.  That’s something I haven’t been in in a long time.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: When you were a girl did you go to the fairs?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Uh huh!  We went—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: When you were a youngster?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Do you remember any stories about the fair?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Not too much.  But I remember, let’s see.  The first time I went to the fair, I thought my grandmother was along, and I believe she was, she was just about in everything!  But that’s been so long ago.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: In the early days did they have pottery at the fairs?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Just after you were married.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  First I’ve known of, except the expositions in Columbia and Charleston.  You know, things like that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Now, your grandmother didn’t go to the Corn Exposition?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, my granddaddy did.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, did he go?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He went to the Columbia one, I know.  I don’t know if he went to the Charleston one or not, but I know he went to the one in Columbia.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That was the corn exposition.  But she didn’t go along?  Did he tell you about it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I remember him having on an Indian suit; I remember that.  Seeing him dressed up, you know; that’s about all I saw.  He had a picture of hisself taken, you know, taken down there.  But I don’t know what my grandmother ever did with that picture!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I know she had it, unless Furman got it.  Furman stayed with her a long time.  But I don’t know what became of that picture.  But he went down there and stayed two or three days a week, I guess I don’t know which it was.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It was a long time.  I don’t remember.  About 20 people went.  I know that Doris went.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Did Doris go?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yeah, she was only—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She went with her mama and daddy, with Rosie?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was the nigger’s name?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Hence Henbrick.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And they found Hence Henbrick chopped up in the river?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, down at the bank of the river, cut to death.  And she was—her hands and feet was tied behind her and throwed in the river, and I guess she just drowned.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: This happened in York County, not in—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That was in Gaffney.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That was up in Gaffney, up there on the Broad River.  Do you know a name “Bolware?”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Bolware?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yeah.  Nellie Bolware.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I found her mentioned in the school play, and I was wondering.  Tell me what happened with the Ayers family, that whole episode with all those deaths.  That must have been awful.  The mother died—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: The mother died with pneumonia.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who was she?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She was Aunt Sallie Gordon’s daughter.  She was my, she was Irvin’s sister.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And what was her name?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Ruthie Gordon.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Ruthie Gordon Ayers.  And she married Johnny?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She married Johnny Ayers.  And she died and left Hazel, oh, five kids, I guess.  There was Johnny, Ruthie, Mary—that was four children.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: There was four children.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Ruthie was just six months old when she died.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Nothing to do with influenza?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, she just up and had pneumonia and just died with it.  You know, it seems strange.  You hear a lot of people having pneumonia now, and—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Nothing.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Nothing.  But now, back then it was fatal.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Just like influenza.  Now, you get the flu and you just go to bed, unless you have other problems.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  And Six months later, you see, he died.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What did he die of?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: With pneumonia, too.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, really?  Oh, wasn’t that a mess!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It was.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh!  And what on earth happened?  What did they do?  Well what did they do?  What did he do when she died?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I believe Aunt Sallie went up there and stayed with them.  You see, that was her daughter, and she stayed with them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Tended the baby?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Taking care of the baby.  And then when he died, there they was.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So she had them all.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She had them all.  And she wasn’t able, so Irvin, you see—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She was old by this time.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, she was old.  And they brought them home there after the funeral.  My sister had them, helped them up.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So actually, Eliza Gordon raised—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Helped to raise—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Helped Sallie Gordon raise all these children.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  They all stayed there at the house.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh my goodness!  But no Social Security?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Nothing?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I think he had a little bit of insurance, but it didn’t last too long.  A little, but it wasn’t too much.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That was a tragedy.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It was.  It was a tragedy.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She didn’t—there’s no obituary for the wife, but there is an obituary for him.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Ruth Gordon?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I don’t think so.  But there was one for him, and it said he left four small children.  But then, that didn’t explain exactly what happened.  So Sallie Gordon and Eliza Gordon actually raised those children.  So you were pretty close to them also.  Did you help?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, I was over there from time to time.  All them kids liked me.  To this day, they all call me “aunt.”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Fox does.  He’s very fond of you, very.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, he does, too.  And also Ruth.  They all call me aunt.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That must have been really rough at that time, when people had no—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, no income or nothing.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Of course, they had to turn to each other.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  Everybody helped them out a little bit here and a little bit there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Sallie Gordon must have been a very good person.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She was, she was.  Ah, now they said she was like John Brown.  Now she had a temper when she was young, but when I knew her, she was just as humble an old woman you ever wanted to know!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She thought a lot of me; she always treated me good, and I always liked her.  I thought a lot of Aunt Sallie.  I helped them take care of her when she died—right up there—and my sister took care of her, and I’d go over and help her with her.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I sure did hate it when she died.  She was a good old soul.  Now talking about telling stories, she could tell you stories from way back!  She could just sit and talk.  Yeah, she could sit and tell you things; and I enjoyed talking to her.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I was telling Billy, my grandson, the other day, “You want me tell you a story about your granddaddy, your great-granddaddy?”  And he said, “What is that, grandma?”  “Well, that was when your granddaddy had to wrestle with the devil one time.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He said, “What?”  And I said, “Yeah, he went way up the river somewhere, but I don’t know whether he. . .”  You know he played a fiddle?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: This was Epp?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, this was Billy’s granddaddy, Peter Harris.  You heard them tell of Peter Harris?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.  Okay.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I said, “He went off.  He played over until Sunday morning.”  But I believe he was playing for white people.  But anyway—“It was somewhere way up the river, and he was coming home.  And he said he met a man.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he said, ah, and the man said, ‘Let me see your fiddle.’  And he said he handed him the fiddle.  And he said that he played it; he played the same thing that Peter Harris could play.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It was ‘The Devil’s Dream,’ that’s what it was called, and he said that man played it just as good as he could!  And then he said before he left, he said he grabbed him and said, ‘Let’s wrestle!’

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he throwed him down, the man throwed him down, and he said, ‘I was a stout man,’ and he said, ‘I was a big man myself, and that man throwed me down!’  And he said, ‘When I got up, I looked at his feet, and he had one foot like a cow or a horse hoof and the other one was like a man!’

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he said the man got up and left, and he went on home.”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And this is Peter Harris?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  And they always said it was the devil that he wrestled with.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But he played?  So a lot of people played music?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  I told Bill it looks like he’d have some musical abilities about him.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Your husband’s grandfather on that side of the family?  Isn’t there a story about a watch, about a man that couldn’t tell time?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That’s Davis Ayers.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, he had a pocket watch, and he couldn’t tell time.  And if anybody asked him, “What time is it?” he’d say, “See for yourself,” and he’d let you look at it.  That’s the way he had to do you, because he couldn’t tell you!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He didn’t want for you to know that he couldn’t tell time?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  He’d say, “See for yourself,” and pull that watch out, and then let you see it.  But he carried that watch.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Always had that watch with him?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Do you remember Billy George?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  I was just talking to Billy, my grandson, about him the other day, and he was asking me, “Well, what was the people like?”  And I said, “One thing, they were honest people.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You didn’t have to lock your doors.  And one thing I can tell him about Billy George—Landrum George’s—I said, “One time he got drunk, of course.”  I said, “And he got so drunk!  He was in a barroom somewhere, and this man couldn’t wake him up and couldn’t get him out the door.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: So they just locked him up and just left him in the barroom, you know, all alone.  And he said sometime in the night or in the morning, Billy George woke up.  And you know how people is—he had the, I guess, something like the DTs, you know.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He was trembling and needing another drink.  And he just sit there until that man come to open up, and all this whiskey around there, and he could have got it, but he didn’t bother a thing.  And when he come in, he asked that man could he have a drink.  And he said he looked at him.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Now, this white man was the one that told him; Billy George didn’t tell.  The white man told it.  And he said, ‘Do you mean to tell me that you have been sitting here like this, and with all this whiskey around here, and you haven’t touched none?’

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He said, ‘No, sir.  I was waiting for you to come in and so I could ask.  I wasn’t bothering what you had unless you give it and let me have it.’  And he could have got it, you see.  He was in there with it, but he wouldn’t touch a thing until he got. . .”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I wonder—would you say that Mormonism has done the Catawbas a great service by stopping the drinking?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I think so.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: At least slowing it down.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It’s decreased.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Do you think it’s decreased?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah, I think it has.  It’s helped people, I think.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It’s helped with education too?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah.  That’s one thing the church believes in: people get an education.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Do you remember those early Mormon missionaries?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, I don’t.  I guess that was before my time, before we were affiliated with the Mormon people; I don’t know too much about it.  You know, my people belonged to another church, and they just stayed with what they had, you know, and didn’t go to another church.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They didn’t pay any attention to the Mormons?  Do you remember any weddings?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I remember some after I got up a good size, I guess.  Going to church where they had them in church.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did people get married in the Baptist church out there?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  They had several down in the Mormon Church, the elders of it.  Most people used to go to the courthouse and get married, you know.  That’s where I was married; I got married in the courthouse.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh!  You didn’t get married in the church?  Oh my!  Well tell me about that.  How did you meet Mr. Harris?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I grew up with him on the reservation.  Knew him all my life.  Didn’t know I was going to marry him someday though!  Yeah, I knew him all my life; we grew up together, went to school together a lot.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And then as he got older, he used to come around the house a lot.  We always played together, and then, when he got older, he’d got up to where he’d come around to see me.  They said that that was what he was after, so finally we, we went together a long time, maybe a year or two, before we got married.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Off and on we’d go for a while.  Then I started going with him again just a little while before my mother died.  Then after she died—I guess that’s one reason why I got married, nothing to hang on to, and I was just by myself with my two brothers.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And as long as she lived—I don’t know; I never thought about getting married.  And probably I wouldn’t have married for a long time.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, you had a position in the house there with your mother, security.  So you just went to the courthouse?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, we went to the courthouse; got married there in the courthouse.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: In York?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Married in York courthouse.  It was in 1927 on April the 23rd.  I think I was married 35 years—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you have a honeymoon?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, just come back and started keeping house.  Of course, I was keeping house anyway.  Just kept on keeping house.  Back then, people didn’t have no money; kind of during the early Depression then.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did Depression time have an effect on the Catawbas, or were they already in a Depression?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I guess it was just a—I guess you could say it was already a Depression among them.  But you know the people on the outside didn’t do any better than the Catawbas were living.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It was the same everywhere.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  It was the same; everybody was in the same boat.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So, really, the Catawbas were no poorer than their neighbors?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Than their white neighbors, no.  In some ways, not as bad as some of them I seen.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, like what did you see out—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, you saw a lot of little kids who didn’t have any shoes to wear and little raggedy clothes.  Well they was in worse shape than the Catawbas were.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Of course the Catawbas had a home.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, that was one thing.  They had a place to stay.  And, of course, you know, the government was giving them a little subsidy.  It wasn’t much—about $.35 a head.  Of course you could take that and buy clothes with it if you wanted to.  Of course most of them did.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That was what they did with that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They’d take it and buy clothes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, when did you get this money, this $35?  Did you have to go to the court, or—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It used to come about the first of the spring, along about April or May, somewhere along in there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So then they’d notify you?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We had an agent, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Flowers?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  Flowers and whatever agent; you know, we had so many.  We had a lot of them.  But anyway, the agent would, the money would come to him, and the state paid him to pay it out, don’t you see.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So—okay.  Your mother was a widow?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How would she proceed?  Now so much money was due to her, how would she proceed to get the money?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She’d have to go up there, and let the man write her a check for it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And she would get a check for you and Jesse and Furman, and then she would do as she pleased with it, and usually she bought clothes?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, if that was needed.  Now in the summer time we went bare-footed, and in the winter time she’d get us shoes to do us through the winter, don’t you see, to be sure we did have.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Or if we needed a coat or something we bought something like that.  But now, as far as our clothes, she usually made our—the girls’—the dresses.  She had to buy, you know, pants and things for the boys.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s right—there was the four of you!  I keep forgetting Eliza.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You see, that’s the way she did: she did all of the sewing for our clothes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She did all of the sewing?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And she made her own clothes herself.  Well that’s a saving, you know, because you could get material for 10 or 15 cents a yard, you see.  Wasn’t no problem.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So this $35—how much was it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Somewhere around $35.  I think they raised it to $45 at the last, but that’s after my mama died.  That’s been since me and my husband got—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So that would be a good amount of money?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Kind of come out of nowhere, and that actually was a boost.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, that would help for—the reason they put it off in the spring time was because a lot of people farmed, and that helped them to get seed and fertilizer for their farm, don’t you see?  They did that for the, to help the—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well this must have been a happy time around the house.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, naturally it would.  Everybody would go to town.  Everybody going to town.  “It’s drawing money day!  Let’s go to town!” and “Here we go!” they would say.  That’s true; it was kind of a boost.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And, of course, white people weren’t getting this.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I wonder if they were offended by that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know whether they knew we were getting it or not; back then, the papers didn’t put things in like they do now.  Now they put everything in.  A lot don’t need to be in there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s true.  Well, of course the merchants would know.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They was right there, ready to get everything.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, where did you all shop?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Uptown.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: In Rock Hill?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You didn’t go to Van Wyck?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, we did if there was something over there you wanted.  Usually town was the closest.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Tell me about going to West Virginia.  You told me one time about that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, that was during, must have been, 1926.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: After you finished school?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That was getting to be a hard winter, and I knew, ah, this woman that lived up there that Ernest Sander knew when he was in the service—that was after his wife died.  He got to know her.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They was about to get married, and he got sent away and all; but she always wrote to him.  And he told her about me, and she wrote to me.  And they owned—she had married—they owned this store, and she always wanted me to come and see her.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And she had wrote to me a long time, and it got to where she said that they needed somebody to come and work for them, and she wanted me to come up there and work for them.  And I said, “Yeah, I’ll come up there and work.”  So I went up there and worked.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How’d you get up there?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Rode the train.  Took the train up there, and I stayed the winter up there.  Come back the next spring.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was it like?  Did you work in the store?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, I worked in the store.  It was a mining town.  It was a little town.  It was named Barnabus, West Virginia, and they had a big, ah, you know—they sold to these miners.  Oh, you worked [?] when you stayed there.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We worked sometimes until 10 o’clock at night.  You see, them miners didn’t get paid off—let’s see, it was every two weeks, I believe—and when they got paid off, buddy, they’d come in and spend their money!  And, you see, it was a general merchandise store.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So they had clothes?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They had clothes and they had food, groceries.  You see, people would, well, you see, they’d stock up for two weeks or a month—however they got paid.  And we worked until 10 o’clock at night.  You couldn’t stop to eat supper!  We’d just work, work, work!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just filling orders!  They’d come in with orders that long, and you’d have to fill them!  They delivered them, too, you see.  And they had a delivery truck, and they’d go way up back in them mountains.  There was some 20 or 30 miles from the store there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Those little hollows?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  And see, we just kept those orders coming.  We’d have a time!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Sure.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I remember one night, I was so tired, I, and we, and they said, “Well go on in there and get whatever you want to eat.”  And I used to like these—what you call them?—these little weenies in the can?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Viennas?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Viennas. I went and got me two cans of them. I could have got me lunch meat—they had it—but I’ve never been a person to eat lunch meat. I don’t know why. I smelled it so much, getting it out and selling it, I just didn’t want it.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I went in there and got me two cans of viennas, and, I guess I was so hungry, I ate those. And way in the night I woke—I didn’t know what was wrong with me!  And I woke up.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I was just so sick, and all at once I heard my stomach rolling. Lord, I had to jump and run! Oh!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Isn’t that awful!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, I just vomited something terrible! And, you know, it took me a long time before I could ever eat a Vienna again! I didn’t want to even smell of them! I’m just now getting back to where I could eat them; but it took me a long time before I could even eat one.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They were bad; they must have turned in the can.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I just think we was tired. I believe that’s what did it. And we just eat and then hit the bed right on it—that was another thing. They just made me sick! But I never will forget that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was the lady’s name that you worked for?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Roby.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That was her last name?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  Mr.—her name was, ah, uhmm . . .  But Mr. and Mrs. Charles Roby.  He was a Jew or something.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Were they fair to the miners?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I’ve heard tales about the miners, about the way they suffered from those stores.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They were good.  They done fair with them.  I thought they done real good.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: The prices were comparable to Rock Hill?  The same?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who was the first Catawba to go to work in the cotton mills?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I believe—Lewis Gordon, I believe.  As far as I remember.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Was that a long time ago?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Wouldn’t have been too long ago.  I believe it—19--?  Is that little dog outdoors?  I think they’re both in here.  But anyway, I think Lewis Gordon was the first one in there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That would be Irvin Gordon’s father?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  He was the first one, if I remember right.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And then other people started to work.  Would you say that that’s the first real, steady money that came into the Catawbas?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Lewis Gordon had moved to Rock Hill and got him a job up there.  And then, I think, Irvin went to work too.  You know, different ones, they seen that somebody needed to get a job, somebody else would try.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I wonder why it took so long for the Catawbas to go to work in the cotton mills.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, nobody wouldn’t hire them.  They went, but they wouldn’t hire them.  Thought theirself too good, I guess.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They just didn’t think an Indian would work?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Didn’t think he’d work, or didn’t want him around them, one.  I don’t know.  Could have been that, you know.  And Indians have always been the type of people they wouldn’t push theirself off on nobody.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Right.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They won’t push theirself on nobody.  Rather than knuckling down to somebody, they’d just stay away.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So they just stayed away until Lewis Gordon came along?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, that makes sense; that sounds natural.  That might be the same problem with the Nesbit clay hole now.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: What’s that?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Is that people think that Mr. Nesbit won’t let them use the clay, so rather than bother—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I said, well, I was going.  She can’t do but one thing, and that’s say, “Well, you can’t get it.”  I ain’t afraid to ask her.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You’ve never been like that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You’ll always—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: If I felt like people didn’t want to fool with me, I wouldn’t push myself on them.  I would do that.  Well, now, I would think, “Now, if you don’t want anything to do with me, I ain’t going to trouble you.”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Do you think that’s the basic thing that separates the Indian from the white man?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It has a lot to do with it; it’s the pride that the Indians have.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They’re not pushy.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, they’re not pushy, and they’re too proud to ask.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What else would separate the Indian from the white man?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But I know, far back as I can remember, if you felt yourself better than them, I’m not going to push myself on them.  I think myself as good, and I’ll just stay away too.  So that’s really been the idea of a lot of them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: There is that tendency to stand back and not, not—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, and not go forward, because “he won’t want to fool with me; so rather than be pushed off, I’ll just stay away.”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So they simply stayed on the reservation.  What kind of work do you think Lewis Gordon did?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know.  He worked in the mill, but I don’t know what kind of work he did.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was he like?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, Lewis Gordon was a likeable fellow.  I liked him.  He was a great talker!  You never seen nobody that talked more than Lewis!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he could just sit and talk and Irvin used to say, “Oh, you get and you see a bunch of women laughing, you know my daddy is somewhere close!”  He could have them laughing!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He was terrible to tell some joke or something, you know.  He had them laughing, and they loved to stay around and talk to him.  Irvin got to where he talked a lot after he got older.  He didn’t for a long time.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Very quiet.  He didn’t; but before he died, he would talk quite a bit.  But he used to fuss about his daddy talking so much: “Daddy talks so much!”  And I liked Lewis Gordon.  He was a little bit funny, but he was—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What do you mean “a little bit funny”?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, he had certain ideas about anything.  He was, I don’t know—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What were these ideas?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I just can’t describe him.  Like, if he felt like—just like him and Old Man Sam Blue: they never did see eye to eye, they didn’t.  He’d just tell you like it is.  Lewis Gordon, he’d just tell you right flat; he didn’t dress it up, or try to—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He didn’t like Sam Blue?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, they didn’t fall out, I don’t think, or fight or nothing like that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They just weren’t friends?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Their ideas just didn’t go together.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Was that on religion?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, that too.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, what was Lewis Gordon’s ideas about religion?  Was he a real—?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, he wasn’t a real religious fellow, I can tell you that!  But he’d treat you good.  I always liked Lewis Gordon; I don’t know why I always liked him.  He was always good to me.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I remember one time somebody was going to jump on me—he was an old man then, too.  He got a stick, and he said, he said, “Walk in front of me.”  He said, “As long as you walk in front of me, nobody is going to touch you!”  And he was going to hit that thing too!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who was going to jump you?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It was Cora Easter.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Cora Easter!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Cora, Cora George.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Why was she going to jump on you?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, she got jealous.  You see, that was Roy Brown’s, she was liking him.  I think Roy was dating Cora, that’s what.  He married Cora.  Yeah, he was married to Cora.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, Cora, that Cora.  I seen a picture.  She was beautiful.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She was a good-looking girl.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh yeah.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And, ah, we was going to the graveyard.  She did, she jumped me!  She grabbed me, and I tore her dress off of her.  I grabbed it and snatched her, but somebody ran and caught us.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I tried to keep her from doing it.  I said, “Now Cora, quit!  There’s a funeral going on!  Let’s not start this.”  She said, “Yeah?  I heard so-and-so.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I said, “Go on, Cora.  I don’t want to fool with you.”  And she run over there and grabbed me!  And when she did, I reached over there and grabbed her.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Her dress?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Tore it all down the front.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh my!  I can’t imagine you doing that!  That’s a different side of Mrs. Harris.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That’s Mrs. Harris when she gets mad!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: A little John Brown there.  Oh, my goodness!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh me!  And, ah, somebody stopped us, and that’s when—and Lewis heard it, he was out there at the cemetery, and he come on; he marched right out there and got me right there!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: There, in front of me he said, “Come on.  There ain’t a soul that’s going to bother you!”  And he marched me straight to his house, to the side of it, and he said, “Nobody is going to bother you.  I’ll see to it.”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well what was she mad at you about?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Roy.  Because I was—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh she was?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: --dating Roy.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You were dating Roy?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, I wasn’t dating Roy.  I never dated.  But Roy always has liked me; I don’t know why—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: --he liked you so much?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He always has liked me.  And Roy ran up the side—we walked down the, we was going down to the graveyard, and he walked with me, talking to me.  And she saw us, you know, and, ah, so she jumps on, I guess she jumps on me instead of jumping on Roy.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But I never said anything to Roy, you know.  Roy likes to tease, and we was just talking going down there, you know; there wasn’t nothing to it.  And that’s what she got mad at!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, so she was, was she--?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Marvin’s half-sister.  Marvin George and Queeley George’s half-sister.  Easter.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who was her mama?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Her name was Easter.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, Easter George.  And who was her mama?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Nan Harris.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But now Cora was—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Easter’s daughter.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Almost all white.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, she was.  Ah, I don’t know who Cora’s daddy was.  He was a white man.  She had Cora before she married Johnny George.  And she already had Cora, and then she had these other three babies.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She was, like, illegitimate, and then she had—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: --then she had several Indian children?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, Cora had some Indian, and then she—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, she had some.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: --but then she had some with more Indian?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But me and Cora always got along, but, you see, we went to school at Cherokee together.  Yeah, then she got mad at me.  And then, after that, she got to be my friend again, and she was good to me.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Whose funeral was it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t remember.  It was some small—I think it was some kid.  As far as I remember, some child.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: This was at the old graveyard?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Down at the old place.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Down at the old place, ah.  Why did they stop using that old cemetery?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, because they didn’t have enough room, I guess.  You know—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Just got—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Crowded.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Do you remember when they used the cemetery across at the Nesbit farm?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  That was a long time ago.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That was before your time?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That was a long time ago!  I’ve been to that place.  You know, they say that they graded that place down.  Now I didn’t know that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Right.  That’s not nice.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It ain’t nice.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He said he didn’t know there was a graveyard in there, but—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Sure he did!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Everybody did.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Everybody else did.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Jesse told me about going over there and digging up, digging the graves— Looking for stuff.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, they went over there and dug some.  I went over there one time.  I never will forget.  Me and Guy Garcia’s brother, and Douglas.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Douglas Garcia?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, my husband.  And we heard somebody coming, talking.  And I run and jumped in the grave, and it tickled old Guy Garcias!  “Brother,” he said, “I always seen people put in their grave, but I never did see anybody jump in the grave!”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Because I went and jumped in the grave!  I was hiding, you know.  I thought the Nesbits was coming, you know.  What happened, it was some of the old, some of the Indians from across the river over here that had gotten over theres to just rambling around.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So what—you actually dug a hole?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  We had dug down in there, see.  Guy’s brother wanted to see what they had, what they buried them—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was his name?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Ben.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: This was Ben Garcia?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, the one that married Rachel’s sister.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Okay.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He wanted to go see what they were, how they was buried.  Ben wanted to.  He was the one that give us the notion of going over there.  I said, “I don’t want to go over there and fool with no dead people!  You won’t find nothing; you won’t find a person there.”  “We’ll find something.”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you find anything?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We found the bones and we found how they were buried.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, you did find bones?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  You know, they were all shredded up.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: All?  No pottery?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We just found pipes.  No, we didn’t see no pipes.  We did—I don’t think we dug but about one.  They dug a vault, like, and I guess they wrapped you up in blankets—I don’t know what—and buried you.  And then they’d take, they had a little wood, cut about that size, and that covered that whole grave.  And it was lined.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, like saplings?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, all over the hill, the top of it, you see; and then dirt was put over the top of that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And when you dug down and you found this old wood—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, for goodness sakes!  So they weren’t buried deep?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah, they were buried deep.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They were deep?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You must have worked!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, we did.  It, I believe it was on a Saturday or a Sunday—I don’t know which it was.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You dug all day?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We were there digging.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh my goodness.  Well, did anybody find anything over there?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  We didn’t dig, but I think one or two graves—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, did anyone ever find anything?  Like Jesse, or anyone?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I wonder if that was it.  Stevens was buried over there?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You mean Thomas Stevens?  No, he is buried over here in the old graveyard.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He is in the old graveyard?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Didn’t you see that?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I’ve been down there.  Maybe we’ll go down there this week.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Okay.  He’s buried down there because I think he’s got a tombstone.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He might.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Thomas Stevens.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I know Allan Austen, Allen Harris has a tombstone.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You see, he was, ah, he froze to death the very year that I was born—1905.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: 1905.  Tell me how that happened.  You told me before.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We were living down there at the ferry—that’s where my dad was—and he came down there.  And my mother said they tried to get him to—she said it was drizzling rain, and she tried to get him to spend the night.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he was going to some white people’s house, friend’s of his that lived beyond where—from the river down there don’t you see.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Over in Lancaster?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  And mama said she didn’t get him to eat supper, I believe, but he didn’t even want to eat, he said.  He could make it, he said.  And she said, “Well, it’s raining and it’s too bad for you to get out.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And it was cold, and she said that he said, “Oh, I’ll be over there before long, before it gets too dark.  I’ll get over there.”  And you know, he tried; and they said where he fell in the little ditch, it wasn’t no more than about that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Couple feet deep?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: One of those drainage [ditches] on the side of the road?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I guess that’s what it was.  And he couldn’t get out.  I guess he was old, you know, and got cold, I imagine, you know, and he just froze to death.  That was in 1905.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did your grandmother tell you anything about him?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I heard my mother talk about him a lot.  You know he was never married; he was an old bachelor.  They always said, I think, if he could catch them, he loved children.  But they said when he would play with them—and he’d always pinch them and have them cry—he played too rough with them, you know.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But he’d always love to play with the kids, my mother said.  But before he’d get through, my mother said, he would have them crying.  He just didn’t know how to play.  But he would always want to fool with children.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who did he stay with?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know who he stayed with.  They said he stayed by hisself mainly.  A lot of people don’t want to stay with nobody, but my mother always liked him.  But I remember she said he’d get after Jesse and then make the little ones cry, and she’d say, “Now alright, Thomas Stevens!”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, really?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  He’d play with the children until they’d cry, you know.  And she said he was always fooling, because Uncle Thomas was like that.  Wherever there was kids, he always wanted to fool with them, so I always figured he must have loved them, you know, but just didn’t know how to—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He’d never had any of his own?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So you were born over there when your daddy was ferryman?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, he was the ferryman.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Tell me about that ferry.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: All I know, he was a ferryman there for--I don’t know how long he was down there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Was it by hand?  Did he have to pull the boat by hand, or . . .?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, I think they had a cable on it maybe, but they had to keep it level, you know, where it would go every night.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: One car at a time?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, they took two or three.  I think it was either two or three.  It wasn’t any cars then; it was mostly wagons, you know.  People wanting to sell cotton from one place to another.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Do you remember him doing that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  I wasn’t but about—I was born there, you see.  We left there when I was about, I was born in July, and we left there, I believe, on Christmas day.  So I must have been four-and-a-half or five months old.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Just still a baby when you left.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, just a baby.  Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He actually wasn’t ferryman for very long.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know how long he stayed down there before I was born, but I know I was born there, not too far off the river there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did your mother ever tell you about his wife Fannie?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, I don’t believe, now, if she knew too much about her or not, you know.  My daddy was a lot older than my mother, he was a lot older.  I think there must have been 20 years or more between them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, really?  Oh!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Now he had, I think, a couple kids by Fannie, but they were stillborn, I think.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, isn’t that sad.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And then she died.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And then he married your mother.  Now, your mother was Epp Harris’s only child.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: His only child.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: After he had the ferry who took it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know who got it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It was always Indian-operated, wasn’t it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Most of the time, I think.  I don’t know who took it after my daddy.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I think John Brown had it for a while.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He had it for a long time; kept it for a while because I remember going down there.  John Brown had a picnic down there one time—I told you how he liked to have picnics.  He had a picnic, and we went down there.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Everybody went on, you know, had a good time down there, stayed all day!  But he always liked people to be around him.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He [was] just the party!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  Fish soup, and everybody’d carry a lunch.  We had a conference at our church last Sunday, and we had a picnic.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh really?  I bet that was fun.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We had a fun meeting in the morning, and then we got out and had lunch.  Everybody carried a picnic basket that wanted to stay, you know.  And then we had visitors from Charlotte, the Charlotte branch of the church up there.  We had visitors come down here, so we had to feed them, too; and we had plenty to eat.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, church has always been a center of social life for the Catawbas.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Kind of a gathering place.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It’s always been important.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  If it wasn’t for the church, I don’t know what they would’ve—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Who had the first car down there?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Don’t ask me!  John Brown?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did he have the first car?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, John Brown.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And do you remember it?  Or remember him with it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah, I remember.  But he never did learn to drive it though!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He didn’t?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, he didn’t!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How come?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know why he couldn’t learn to drive that car.  Roy drove it all the time.  We used to, I used to get right tickled when—ah, they lived down at the ferry—when Roy hit the lower end of the rez, he’d start blowing that horn and he blew it all up through the rez to go up there to where near Doris lives because he used to live near, right below, Doris’s house.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And you’d hear it, and, well, everybody would say, “Well, John Brown’s in town.”  They’d hear that horn blowing!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What kind of car was it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It was, ah, one of those old, ah—it was a Ford, I know.  Double seat—what you call them things?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I don’t—sedan?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, it wasn’t a sedan because it had to have—put up curtains around it, you know?  I know what you call them things and I can’t say it!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Model T?  No—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah!  It had to have been a Model T!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Model T?  It must have been—well, that job down on the ferry was a good paying job evidently.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: When he was paying.  I know it had went up, you know.  But when my dad was on the ferry it wasn’t too much, I just imagine.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That might have been the only job.  Do you think at one time that was the only job available to a Catawba man?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know whether it was or not.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Do you remember the men cutting cord wood?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, my husband used to do that, did that a lot.  He used to go over there and cut—I was just telling Billy about that the other day.  My husband, you know I told you he farmed?  And in the winter time maybe he’d say, “Well, I got to have something else.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And, you know, he’d want a little more than what we got to eat.  He’d always [say], “I think I’ll go see Dr. Jim, Dr. Furman, and see if I can get some wood to cut.”  And he’d go over there.  Dr. Jim always give him money; he could always get wood to cut.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How much would he make?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I knowed for my husband to make $10 a week!  Nobody else ever done that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That was a lot of money?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It was at that time, because I remember he used to go get groceries and he’d have four or five dollars left!  And now, Roy went over there and cut with my husband, but nobody could—Landrum George is the onliest one could almost come up cutting wood even with my husband.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was this with?  An ax?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: This was with an ax.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh my!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And my husband wasn’t no big man.  He was tall and slim, but he could swing an ax.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So he would make maybe $10 a week doing that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  And about every week he made $10.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How much wood would he have to cut to make $10?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I said that’s what I was telling Billy the other day, you know.  They’d make a cord of wood—depends on what kind of wood they were cutting.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Sometimes they would cut what you call ‘stove wood,’ and you’d pin it, you know.  And I believe you got to put, is it—ah, how many pins you got to have in a cord?—five, I believe.  And then you cut the two foot—wood is, ah, 18 feet long by 2, and how many feet high?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: About [?] feet high.  And maybe they did, I think they paid them for that 18 feet long—I believe that’s the 2 foot.  I believe they got either a dollar and a half or two dollars a cord.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Two dollars a cord.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Now that’s a lot of cutting, you know?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s a lot of work!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It was.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: An awful lot of work!  He must have worked very hard to do that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But he could do it, and he wouldn’t be as tired as some of the rest of them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Sure.  Now, did he do this up until he went to work in the mill?  Or he never worked in the mill?

text.speaker: NOTE
text.text_bit: THIS PORTION OF THE INTERVIEW IS MISSING FROM THE AUDIO RECORDING.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I believe the year—Dewey was born in ’36.  And I don’t know where it was, how long he worked; but he had a friend that lived in Lancaster—I believe he used to play ball with him.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he went—he had been working off from home, and he wanted Douglas to go with him.  Douglas didn’t go the first time he went.  He kind of promised him and then he backed down.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But the times was beginning to get kind of rough, so he told him next time.  This boy asked him to go with him, and he went with him.  And that’s how he got out in the public—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s the first time he went out in the public except when he worked in the mill that one time before you were married?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, and then worked on the WPA.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What did they do on that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: The WPA?  Well, they dug ditches and set out trees, things like that.  Pine trees and stuff.  But he had to dig ditches for a while, I know he did.  He said, “Well, I worked hard when I had to work on the WPA.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: A lot of people said that was a play job, but don’t tell me it was!  It might have been in some places, but I didn’t play.”  He said, “When I had to dig ditches,” he said, “you worked for that!”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yeah, that’s hard work any way you want to do it.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, it is!  Yes sir.  Dig ditches.  And that’s another thing my husband said; he said he put many a man out digging them ditches.  He stayed right in there with them.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But I said he’d always been used to working because his daddy worked him ever since he was a little boy on the farm.  He always worked.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was his daddy like?  Do you remember his daddy?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, I remember his daddy.  His daddy died, though, I guess about two years we were, my husband and I were married.  Yeah, he was, his daddy was a hard worker.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He worked hard.  He always did work, that’s what my husband always said:  “Well, my daddy didn’t teach me to like work, but he sure taught me how to do it!”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was his daddy’s name?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: David.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: The son of Peter Harris?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  That’s the reason my husband said, well, he said he just farmed, you know, a while.  Well, it was really—it kept us living during the Depression, I’ll tell you that!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I said.  I thought of many a times I thought we were having hard luck, but since then, since I’ve worked out and heard people [talk] about the Depression—they was in a lot worse shape than I was!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: See, we didn’t have no rent to pay, no light bills, and what we made we had.  Yeah, we didn’t owe nobody.  We had our living, and we raised—I canned a lot of stuff for us through the winter, you know.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We’d have something to eat.  We didn’t have no money—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But you had food and you had a roof.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  You had food, and we had a roof, and we had wood to keep us warm; we didn’t have to buy coal.  I’ve heard of people talking of what a time they had during the Depression—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Trying to buy coal?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, buying coal, had kids to feed, and, ah, rent to pay and they wasn’t making anything, about $7, $8 a week.  And I thought we was having hard times!  I didn’t know other people was too.  You know, it was that—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Had it just as bad or worse.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: A lot of people were evicted from their homes.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That’s right.  They even had bread lines.  People stood in bread lines.  I heard somebody talk the other day about, I believe, somewhere in Pennsylvania they was even in bread lines!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But you never had to do that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, never in my life.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well what would you do when the river came up and ruined your crop?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Go back and start over.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You could do that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  That was all you could do.  But a lot of time it would come in the fall of the year, and took the corn, and it was gone.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Then what would you do?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You’d do the best [could], and if you had any left over from the last year, you’d try to make it last as long as you could.  A lot of times we had some, you know, left over.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Right.  Did you ever lose everything that way?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, ah, some of it you might, if the river didn’t stay on it too long, but a lot of times it would come along and just wipe the crop out.  But you know, I remember one year my husband had planted, ah, Irish potatoes, and we had about fifty.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Usually, you know Irish potatoes are easy to ruin [and] will get ruined if they get water on them.  And he said, “Well, no need to go back and worry about those potatoes.  They’re gone.”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What year was this?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, it was up—Floyd was up, it must have been about 11 years old.  I don’t know, because Floyd was big enough to plow.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So this must have been 1950?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Somewhere in there.  And my husband went down and he said, “No need to worry about those potatoes now.  That water done ruined them.”  And we didn’t.  And next spring he sent Floyd down there to turn that land.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He turned out some of the biggest Irish potatoes!  They was that big!  That long!  Just as smooth and as pretty as you could be!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You could have been eating them all along?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We could have been eating them all winter!  And we thought it had ruined them!  And now they had started, almost ready to sprout.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So could you eat them?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We could eat them, but they was sappy, like, you know, they was getting ready to sprout.  We just had to plow them up, and throw them away.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, did you have to do without that winter?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, we did have, yeah, we didn’t have—we had to buy what we had.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You had money to buy?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, a little bit.  We had to buy.  We wouldn’t have had as much.  You know, after I thought about that, he said, “You know, I never thought about that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That water didn’t stay on there long, and it’s in sandy land and it run off, don’t you see.”  And he didn’t think.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Never thought of that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Never thought of that running off.  But usually, you know, we had some.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: One time, down there below our house, we had to put in, in ordinary land, you know—we had a lot of Irish potatoes in there and it, water got up on them, most of them, [and] we got some of them.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He plowed them up, and we took them and washed them and sold them right quick, what we could.  And got—we knew we couldn’t—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You couldn’t store them.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We couldn’t store them.  And so he thought that was [what] would happen down there, but not thinking about that being in sand, so, you know, the water will run off it quick.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How did you store Irish potatoes?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just put them in boxes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You didn’t put them in the ground?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  We used to, ah—sweet potatoes we used to put in the ground.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You put those in the ground.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Make a hack, you know?  Hack them, as the old saying goes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How do you do that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You have to—you make a mound out here.  You make a place about this high, about 2’ high.  [?]  Now as far around, as big as you are going to make your hack, and put a lot of corn stalks and stuff  on there—shucks—and then you stack your potatoes there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: On top of those shucks?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: On top of those shucks.  And make a big pyramid.  And you stack all your [potatoes].  And then you take you some corn stalks and go all the way around that thing, and—just as thick as you can get them—and take dirt and pile it up around and cover it.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And top it off with a tin tub, and they’ll stay there all winter long.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Now is that an Indian idea, or did everybody do that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Everybody did that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Everybody did it that way.  How about rats?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They didn’t have any trouble with them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: A rat wouldn’t go in there?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I guess they didn’t.  Or we weren’t bothered with rats down there much.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So if you needed some you’d just dig the dirt away?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You’d just have a certain hole that you used, that you opened it, on the south side where the cold air wouldn’t come in.  And they’d do it on clear days; they’d always say, “Go on a clear day.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And they would take out what they need and they’d close it back up and leave it there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Isn’t that interesting.  And you call that hacking?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Hacking.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And what else would you store?  Would you store other things that way?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just sweet potatoes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Just sweet potatoes?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Carrots?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I imagine you could have stored them the same way, but they didn’t try.  Because, you know, sweet potatoes are easy to rot if they get cold, I think; and I guess the earth, the dirt, kept that, sealed that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How about food from the woods?  Did you eat stuff that you gathered, you know, like berries?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah, we used to go out and pick blackberries.  We always picked a lot of blackberries when they was in season.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yeah, and would you can those?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, we’d can them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You’d can them.  Did the children do that, or the adults?  Or everybody?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Everybody picked berries.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: The whole family--

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: --went out and did that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We used to pick them, me and my husband.  You used to go out and pick them and can them.  That helped out too, because they’d just grow wild, and you didn’t have to worry about it.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: If you found a good patch you could get great old big ones, and it didn’t take you long to have a lot of buckets full, and you could go home and can berries all at one time.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you have trouble eating them, or did you have discipline?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, we didn’t have no trouble.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Some people will eat one, pick one . . .

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I never did do that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I don’t either.  When I’m picking, I’m worrying about filling my bucket.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, that’s me.  I never did eat berries when I was picking.  It didn’t take to.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Floyd, he used to do that; he’d run and pick some and then sit down and eat.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Would he?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He was small though.  He’d pick a while and then he’d come back and sit down and go to eating.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And your mama did the same?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  Everybody—everybody!—picked and canned berries.  That was a big thing.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: One, it helped out, you know, making pies and different things, you know.  And it was free, too.  And you didn’t, you know, have to buy—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yeah, sure.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: --them.  I got some in my freezer right now!  There is some right out there, and I went out there and picked them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, what did the pottery have to do with the economy?  Now, if a man cut cord wood and made some money, and if he grew some crops down in the bottoms, and—how would the pottery fit in?  Now, I know, like, Eliza Gordon made a lot of pots.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She sure did.  She fed her family.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s how she fed them?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  She had to feed them.  Yeah, she made a lot more pottery than I ever did.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Was that a necessity in her case?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I guess it was kind of.  You know, Irvin never was too much of a man to work.  He wasn’t as industrious as he should have been.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He got more industrious in his old age than he did when he was younger.  He was kind of lazy.  I liked old Irvin, but he was lazy.  And she always—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So she had to take up the slack?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, she always stayed in it.

text.speaker: TB
