text.text_bit: How did she sell her pots?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, he was good to take them off and sell them at that.  He’d sell them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, he would?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He just wouldn’t go out and cut cord wood?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He’d cut some, but he wouldn’t hurt hisself.  Yeah, he’d cut some, but he wouldn’t hurt hisself cutting too much.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But he was good about—he’d burn pots.  He was good about that with my sister.  Oh, he’d burn them and everything.  Get the wood for her.  She had no trouble about that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And then they used to sell a lot of them right there at the house, you know, right there where Louise lives.  Now you see, they lived right close.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They lived right there?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They used to have a sign out there, and people come in there and bought on Sundays.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So, where Douglas Harris was bringing in extra money from ax handles, Eliza Gordon would get a bunch of pottery.  Well, could they live on the same level that you did?  But I know that she had extra children from the Ayers, though.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Or that was not her financial responsibility?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  Well, ah, Aunt Sallie would help to make pottery too.  She’d make some, so it all went into the same household, you see.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So it was really the two, three of them keeping things going.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, keeping things going.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Of course, they must have had a harder job of it than you did.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They did!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was the difference between the two households?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You know, we always, I said, when my husband—even when he farmed—we always had something to eat because, you know, he always provided for us.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We raised hogs and killed them; for the winter we’d have meat.  I remember many times Irvin would come over and eat with us, you know, at night, because, you know, he knew my husband had [?].

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He’d say, “Who’s hungry tonight?”  And me and my sister used to say “We’re not hungry!”  Because we knew he’d want us to cook, you know.  But we’d laugh.  My, my husband was terrible!  He could cook cornbread.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he’d fix it and say, “Let’s cook some cornbread by the fire.”  And we’d bring out that old skillet, you know, and put it—we’d draw out some coals of course, you know, because we’d have a big old fire in the fireplace.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And we’d have a lot of oak coals—that’s what burns good—and they’d get out the skillet.  And we’d have two of them; put canned meat in one of them, and the other with cornbread.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And my husband drank coffee back then—I don’t know about Irvin; I think Irvin did—and he’d make coffee.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Now, Irvin was a Mormon?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  Then, ah, they’d drink coffee, and when they’d get it done, we’d help them eat it.  He’d say, “I thought you all weren’t hungry!”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But now, he didn’t kill hogs?  He didn’t raise hogs?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So they didn’t have any of that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  The only reason they had it was because he, I think, once in a while, he’d get a little old pig and try to raise it, you know.  But it was very seldom.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They usually had to buy feed for it, you know, or something.  But my husband, you know, he raised.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Sometimes he’d need a little extra feed, buy a little extra feed; buy them a little corn, you know.  That makes hard meat, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That makes a good pork chop?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, it makes good meat.  Makes it firm.  You wouldn’t have this old soft meat.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So if you let them run in the woods and eat garbage, you’re going to get a different kind of meat?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  We always kept ours up.  We didn’t let every one, of course.  One time we had four, and we had one hog, we couldn’t keep it in the pen!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That hog would get out and run all over the place!  And we even had a pit dug, and you know, my husband put that thing in a pit—and that thing was as high as up to that door—and you know that thing come up out of that thing!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He climbed up?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He got out of there!  And my husband felt sure that if he put him down there, that he’d stay.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And sure he come up out of there and he done got up, and I guess weighed around 200 pounds.  And I tell you, there’s only one thing to do with him; that’s kill him—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It was time.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: --and we killed him.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well.  Did you have to kill a pig at a certain time of year?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, then we didn’t have refrigeration, and you had to kill them when it got cold enough to cure it out, you know.  You had to have some cold weather on it to cure it.  And so that’s why you always waited until it got—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So when would you do that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Usually wait until around November.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: November.  Then you kill—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Back then the winters were a lot more severe than it is now.  We don’t have cold weather like we used to.  We used to have real cold, and, ah, then we would kill our hogs maybe around Thanksgiving or—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And then what would you do with all the meat?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, you can can the sausage, you know.  We would can the sausage; and you can cure your other meat out, salt it down, put enough salt on it to cure it out.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So the hams and, ah, ribs—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, the shoulders and stuff.  Well, we’d eat up the ribs in no time!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You’d eat that right away?  Fresh?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  First your back bones and spare ribs won’t last long, you know.  So we’d work on that.  And hams and shoulders, you know.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And then make lard out of some of it, you know.  But we had our lard; we didn’t have to buy no lard, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What would you do with the head?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Make souse meat!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh.  You did use the head for something?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: The reason I ask, they had at, ah, at New Year’s in Washington, they sold the colored people thousands of pig heads!  I went to the market, and there was just heads everywhere!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well here, you know, they believe in eating hog head and black-eyed peas for New Year’s.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s what they did; that’s what they told me.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Do they eat it up in Washington?  I didn’t know that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But the Indians didn’t do that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, yes they do!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, they do?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They’d eat black-eyed peas!  And I laughed at Nola—Nola used to stay with me—I said, “Nola, me and you got to get together for New Year’s.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And she said, “Well,” she said, “I got the collard greens.”  And I said, “Okay.”  And I think she brought them up here, and we had collard greens, black-eyed peas, and—I don’t think we had any hog head, but we had some fresh meat to go with it.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And we eat dinner together; I think the last two years she and I have ate together.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s nice.  She’s a nice person; she really is.  She’s a lot of fun.  Was your husband like her?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Some, yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That same playful?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  He never did get old; he never was old.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He never got old?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did he grow up in great poverty?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I guess, in a way.  He come from a big family.  His daddy always worked hard.  He farmed.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: My husband always farmed; raised cotton, you know.  There’s a lot of work to raising cotton.  Of course, they got more for it than they do now.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But back then, they would go to some man and say, “Well, I’ll give you a lien”—so much money—“for me to run my crop on, and you sell the crop and pay me.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And a lot of times, if it wasn’t a good crop year, you’d have to pay that man, and then you got nothing for yourself.  That’s the way it went.  And the man always paid his debt first.  Most of them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So they had a hard time.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  Back then, yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: The reason I asked, it seems to me that I remember reading somewhere that Maggie Harris had pellagra.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, she did.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She did have it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was that like?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, all that I seen, they said they’d get weak, and they’d get little old scaly things or your arm would break out.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What would it come from?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They said it’s from malnutrition.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But she did have it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, she had it, but she didn’t have it bad.  I remember when she had it; but she didn’t have it too bad.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, was it something you could correct by diet, or—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You didn’t die from it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You would have if you didn’t get the right foods or the right vitamins!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: If you didn’t get some vitamins . . .  You know, I was just reading here—maybe it was today, or yesterday, I don’t know; I pick up so many books to read—but anyway, it said that, ah, have you ever noticed that when, ah, you know, times get hard people die more?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And that’s why: They don’t get the right foods!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They don’t get the right food.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And when they get something, they can’t throw it off.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well what did she die from?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Maggie?  She just died from old age.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Just old age?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  She was old.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But that pellagra was very common?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  White people had it, and everywhere else around here.  I know more people.  But the Indians didn’t.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But the Indians didn’t?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I didn’t remember any Indians having it, as I know of.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: The only people I’ve ever heard of having it would be Maggie Price, Dorothy Price, and Rhoda.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Rhoda Harris?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She had it.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She did?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But now, she was white.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No she wasn’t; she was an Indian.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I don’t know . . .

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You know, that’s what—I don’t know either.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Keep talking.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You know, I wondered about that.  She could speak Catawba.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh yeah, fluently.  So what do you know?  Then I’ll tell you what I know.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I heard one time somebody said that she was white.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She had blue eyes.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, she had blue eyes; I remember that.  I remember her because I remember going up there.  We used to go up to see her and up to Aunt Betsy’s.  Did I ever tell you this?  How scared I got one time?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Tell right now.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I heard Aunt Betsy and Aunt Rhoda, and they was talking Indian talk; and I had never heard it before!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How old were you?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, I must have been about 6 or 7 years old.  And, you know, that scared me!  I wondered what was wrong with those people!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I didn’t say nothing about it.  And I was a kid, you know, just like I said.  And I went home and told my mama.  I said, “Mama, I got scared to death!”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And she said, “What of?”  And I said, “I heard Aunt Betsy and Aunt Rhoda in there saying things”; and I said, “I didn’t know what they were saying!”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And she told me they were talking Indian.  I remembered that so good!  That has lived with me all these years.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I heard that she was white one time, and then again, I heard that she wasn’t; so I don’t know.  What does Doris say about it?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It’s not Doris; it’s Lula.  You remember her?  She died in 1918, around 1918.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, I remember her because Doris was in Cherokee when she died.  I was going to school, and I remember that.  And I believe it was along in October or November when she died.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yeah.  Right.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You ask Doris about that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was Betsy like?  Do you remember any stories about her?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I heard a lot of them, but I don’t know . . .  I don’t know—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You don’t want to tell them?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Don’t tell Doris.  No, I don’t know nothing about Betsy.  Although she said she was an old maid all her life, I don’t know.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And, ah, she was all—everybody used to say they was scared of her.  I don’t know.  We all, you know, we all was kind of like family.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: My grandmother always went to see her, and she always treated us good as far as I know.  I been going there all my life, you know, visiting.  But they always said she was cranky because she was an old maid.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Was she cranky?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: To me?  I didn’t think she was.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She wasn’t cranky to you?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Do you remember anything that she did to you or she said to you?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  She was very—I never did see her—one thing I can say, I never did see her smile much, you know.  I never did see her smile very much.  She was a prim little woman.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She was little?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, she wasn’t so little.  She was—I always thought she was kind of a fancy little woman in her talking and everything, you know?  And she was very clean; I know she was.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did she make pots?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Now that I don’t know; but I think she did.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She must have.  How about Susannah?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Now Susannah, I never knew much about her until I went to Cherokee and saw her.  And that’s when I learned more about Susannah.  Now, Susannah was kind of cranky!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yeah, she was a religious fanatic.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Do you know anything about that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That you’re willing to tell?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  She was a Baptist, and a very, very strict Baptist.  She would get mad at Sampson Owl and give him a fit!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He was, I don’t know, he was very—I don’t know whether, I don’t know what kind of man he was, but he never did say anything, and she would just [?] as long as she wanted to.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What would she get mad at him about?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know.  Something come up, and she’d get mad.  She’d just fuss!  That was Aunt Sue.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But that’s what I remember about her.  Yeah, and she could sit in the rocking chair and she could sing Christian songs!  She was terrible to sit and sing!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Is that right?  And would she sermon?  Would she sermonize all the time?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: A good bit.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Like, what were some of the things that she kept after you about?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, she’d talk about the Bible, you know.  I think she read it a lot.  I think she read the Bible a good bit; but she was a real—what you say?  A religious fanatic.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She was crippled too?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  You know, I wondered about that.  I’ve been intending to ask Doris.  She’d been cripple ever since I knew her, and they said it was arthritis, and I wonder if it was.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And every one of her daughters was like that, except Kamie.  Kamie wasn’t like that.  She had a daughter [?] the one called Ida was the same way.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, was crippled that way?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She hopped whenever she walked, looked like one of the legs was shorter than the other.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It must have been hereditary.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It had to have been something.  Somebody told me somewhere along the way that it was arthritis, but I don’t believe that now after I—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It must have been hereditary.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Because Ida walked just like Aunt Sue!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Anybody else?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, those were the only two.  Now Kamie didn’t, but I remember Ida walking just like Aunt Sue.  They walked like one leg was shorter than the other.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She was very good.  She took in a lot of children.  Her situation was similar to Eliza’s, wasn’t it?  And Sallie Gordon’s?  I think that Ida died and left a lot of children.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, no.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Didn’t somebody die?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Ida did die, but her husband lived a long time and took care of those kids.  And the others was big enough to take care of themselves.  And the school took care of them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh.  They were at the boarding school?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  She didn’t have to take care of them; she didn’t take care of those kids.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How about Agnes?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Agnes Owl?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, Agnes was grown.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: When she took her?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She was a big girl.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She was not a baby?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  She was able to wait on Susannah when she got her.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, is that what she did?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes, I think she—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She was more or less a servant?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, I don’t reckon a servant.  She just took her in, helped her, and let her help her, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She helped the girl by taking her in, and Agnes helped her.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  I think she kept Agnes.  The onliest time Agnes was there was during vacation because she was at boarding school all the time.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She was up at Carlisle, and then, I think, went to Hampton.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Who was that?  Agnes?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Agnes, yeah.  Then I think she went to Haskell or something.  She skipped all over.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t remember about that.  Of course, I knew Agnes was a good-looking girl.  She was a pretty thing!  She was smart, too; she was an RN.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That was a case of just being thrown away?  She was given?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And Susannah took her.  She had a lot of brothers and sisters.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I never did know who they were.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: There’s a lot of people in Cherokee who are her brothers and sisters.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Who claim her now.  Is Agnes dead or is she living?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She’s dead.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She is?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I think so.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I can’t believe it.  She had the cutest little old kids!  I know one of them was named Joseph, the oldest one.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She married a white man, or what?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Married an Indian.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She married an Indian?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I think he was an Indian.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And she was in the Indian Service?  You don’t know who—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I never did see her husband.  She came back to Cherokee, I know that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you know his name?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, I did know his name.  I think his name was Joseph, but I done forgot his last name.  Oh, I knew Agnes; Agnes was a pretty thing.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Okay.  Now, what were you going to say?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh.  I raised a boy; he was a white boy.  And, ah, and I got him—we got him when he was about 8 years old.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And if he’d do anything I’d always get him in and talk to him, and we’d punish him sometimes and make him stay in, you know.  And he’d say, “Well why?  Why is that?”  He’d always want to know why.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: “Because it’s wrong!”  But you know, he couldn’t see the wrong part of it, what he did, you know?  And I said, “Well why did you do it?  That’s what I’d like to know.”  “I don’t know.  But why do you ask me ‘why’?”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I said, “Everything that you do,” I said, “there’s a reason.”  And I said, “When you do something, you do it for a reason.  And I would like to know why would you do something like that.  And you’ve been taught better.  That, that was wrong.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: “Well, I don’t see why.  What’s ‘reason’?”  But he never could understand it.  But I bet he does now.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Was he from a tragedy?  How did you come about—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, the—when we found him, he was over here at my son’s wife’s people.  They kept him.  This man had remarried, and his wife had children by him, by his daddy.  And she mistreated little—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was his name?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Burges.  William Burges.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And we always called him Sonny; that’s all he ever got was Sonny.  But his name was William.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And they had him over there, and these people had a big family themselves.  And she said she wasn’t able to take him and keep him like because she children—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: She just didn’t want to be bothered?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He was a good little boy.  She said he didn’t give them any trouble, but that it was another hand to feed and take care of and she had a big family.  So she told us, she said—one, my husband said, “I would love to have him.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And she said, “Well, talk to him.  He might give him to you.”  And so, ah, she said he can’t keep him at home because his wife won’t let him, or she would mistreat him; so he’d take him and board him out with somebody else, you know.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And so one day my husband saw this man and asked him about him.  He said, “No, I don’t want to give him away.”  He said, “He’s my little old boy!” he said.  “And I just don’t!”  I couldn’t blame the man.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He was his flesh and blood, and he wanted to keep him.  So my husband let him alone.  But when we’d go to town, when we finally went to the [?] over here and took him home.  And every once in a while, when we’d go to town, my husband would say, “Let’s go by and see Sonny.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And we’d go by and give him maybe a bag of candy, you know, something to carry to him.  And we’d go by to see him, and he kept after Mr. Burgess.  “I’d like to have that little boy,” he said.  “I know it, but I want to keep him.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: So we had bothered him, and he said, “I’m going to quit bothering Mr. Burgess about his little boy because,” he said, “I know he wants to keep him.”  So it was a long time before we went down there.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And so one day, we went to town again, and he said, “Let’s go by and see Sonny today.”  And I said, “Okay.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he got something and went down to see Sonny, and—I never will forget it—Sonny’s daddy was laying out there under a car—he was a mechanic and he was working on cars—and he was laying out under the car, and, ah, my husband went over to the car where he was and was talking to him.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I didn’t see Sonny anywhere, but he was in the house.  And, ah, all at once I saw him.  And my husband came over back towards the car, and the old man went in the house.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And then he come, and when my husband got to the car he says, “Ah, we’re going to get Sonny.”  I said, “You don’t mean that!”  And he said that he and his wife were having trouble, you know, about Sonny.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he told Mr. Burgess then, “Now you can come see him anytime you want to.”  He said, “We won’t keep you from seeing him [when] you want.”  And he said, “You can see him when you get ready.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: So when he came back, he had a little pack of clothes.  I bet they wasn’t any more than that big!  And that’s all he brought.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Really?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just a handful.  And, ah, it was in the, along about, I guess it might have been about the last of August—it wasn’t long before school got started, you know.  So we brought him on home.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And after that I went to town, you know, and bought him a lot of clothes so he could go to school.  Dressed him up real good, and, ah, he loved his clothes.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And you know, we bought that little boy underwear, and he never knowed—he didn’t want to put them on because he never, he didn’t know what underwear was!  And I tried to talk to him.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I tried to tell him.  And I’d tell him how my husband wore them.  And you know, he said, “Well, when I get big, I’ll wear them too.”  Poor little thing.  I felt sorry for him.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he had never made a grade because, you know, he’d been picked up and took from place to place, and never made a grade in school.  And I took that little boy and put him up in Northside School, right up here on the hill over here, and, ah, he didn’t want to go to school!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He cried!  He hung on to me!  That day, I carried him to school, but I knew that if I brought him back, the next day would be the same thing.  And I stayed with him and I pleaded with him, and he cried.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He didn’t want to go to school!  And I said, “Well, you must go today and see how it is.”  And he said, “Well, take me home, and we’ll come back tomorrow!”  And I said, “No, tomorrow is another day, and you’ll tell me that tomorrow.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I said, “Let’s stay today and see how it is.”  That’s all I had to do.  After the first day, I didn’t have no more trouble with him, and I got him through school.  Of course, it was a hard struggle.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I got him to high school, and I think he quit after he got older, you know.  You see, he was already old, for as—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He had already set a pattern before you got him?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He wasn’t foster?  You didn’t adopt him?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, we just—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He wasn’t foster?  The man never gave you anything for him?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Isn’t that nice.  Well what is he doing now?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He’s a—I think he works up here by Carowinds somewhere.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Do you ever see him?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I see him once in a while, but not too recent.  Well, when he went with one of the Wesley Harris’s brother’s daughters, I saw him a good bit because I used to come into—he lived at Charlotte for a long time.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I think he lived up here in Ft. Mills now.  But when I used to come to Charlotte, I used to call him up all the time.  And all the time if I come into Charlotte, if I fly to Charlotte, he always come and met me and brought me home.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I saw a lot of him then.  But I haven’t seen him since he married this other woman.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So he’s not married to the Catawba any more?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, they got separated, and he’s remarried.  And I haven’t seen him since then.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Does he have children?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They say he has one, and I would love to see it, I’d like to see it; but I guess he’s just busy.  I saw him a good bit when he was married to the—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well how long—you had him a good, what?  Seven or eight years?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That was really nice.  That was an experience.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But I never will forget.  His daddy drank a lot, and when—somebody jumped on him and beat him, and he died.  And they left him out in the cold, and he took pneumonia and died from it.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Of course, let’s see—my husband died in ’66, and his real daddy died in the following, I believe, in January or February.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I never will forget, he brought me home one day, and—I don’t know how he got to talking about my husband—and he said, “Well, I can say one thing: I got one daddy in heaven and I got one in hell.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I said, “Sonny Bergers don’t say that!  That was your papa!  Don’t say that.”  And he said, “Well mama, you know good and well, mama, that my real daddy went to hell because of the way he done me.”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He said, “You know, he never did one thing with hisself .”

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It’s sad to have to carry that burden.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  He knew the life his daddy had lived.  He drank all his life.  And he said that to me, but I got after him!  “Sonny, don’t say that!”  And he said, “You know mama, my real daddy [?] . . .

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s incredible; it really is.  So you really taught him everything.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just about.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: His manners.  And he was just like a little wild animal when you got him?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Was he good?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, he was kinda—I guess he was the type of person that always felt that he had to fight for hisself, and you can imagine—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He did until you got him.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But he still had that attitude at times, you know, that he felt like that he had to take up for hisself.  You see, he had done that when he was—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They had set that pattern when he was very little.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well how long had he been tossed around between the, his mother—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I’m going to tell you the real truth of it: This man, this boy was an illegitimate child.  It was during the war, and he met this woman, and he had this child.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And they said she came from Spartanburg, SC.  I’ve got her name somewhere though.  But anyway, she came from Spartanburg, and her husband was in the service.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Sonny’s daddy got going with her, don’t you see, and finally she got pregnant with this little boy.  And she was going to leave it here in the hospital and let them give it away.  And he wouldn’t hear of it.  And you know, he took that baby.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She left him, and he took it and he said, “Well, I’ll take it if she don’t want it.”  And she didn’t want her husband to know that she had the child.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And she goes back to Spartanburg so she could, you know, move back with her husband when he come out of the service.  So he takes this child as a baby and raised it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So he wasn’t all bad.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He had a good streak in him.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He had a good streak in him.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You know, they say in every person, regardless of how bad they are, there’s always a good—there’s some good about everybody.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well does this boy know this?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Has he ever seen his mother?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I don’t reckon she’d want to see him.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t reckon she’d claim him, you see, because she just left him.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And the husband never knew a thing?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I guess that happens a lot.  That’s incredible.  So you got him—in what year did you get him?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Let’s see.  He was 8 years old; he was born in ‘42.  ‘50-something.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Around 1950.  You were up here?  You didn’t raise him down on the rez?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We were up here.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Tell me about the Barris family.  You mentioned that they used to live where Lula Beck lives.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, they were missionaries, you know, of the church.  And I think they taught.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Mormons?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  I think they taught school here for a while.  That was a—little, I was small.  I don’t remember too much about them, but I remember them being here.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well. . .  Did they build that house?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I wouldn’t know whether they built it, or how that house came about.  But it was built for them, I think.  Maybe the Indians had it built for them, and that’s where they lived.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How come you never mentioned having turkey on a holiday?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, you know, sometimes we did if we raised any.  If we raised some of our own, we had them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well, did people have turkey back when you were a child at Christmas?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, if somebody raised any, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But usually they had either ham or—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Chicken, because they usually raised chickens.  Because it’s hard to raise turkeys and chickens together, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Why is that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I don’t know why, but they always say it’s hard to raise them two together.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They’ll fuss?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I guess.  I think that’s it.  I know that, if they raised them, they didn’t raise them together.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Now, you mentioned yesterday about your china dolls.  How did you take care of those dolls?  How did you treat your toys, you and Eliza?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, we always made doll clothes for them, you know.  They didn’t come, most of the time, they didn’t come dressed, you know.  They just had the little stuffed bodies.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: The legs would be china, the little arms up to the elbows out would be china, and the rest of it would be stuffed body—cloth, and stuffed.  And the little head was china.  We took—I remember keeping mine for ages.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They would break, yeah.  Because we knew that was all we’d get until the next Christmas, you know.  And we’d always take real good care of them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Those were the only toys you had?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That was the main thing—the dolls—when we was real small.  I remember, because we loved to play with dolls.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well these were tiny.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, they’d be about that high.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh.  They were big, like babies.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  They’d be about 12” high.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But you took care of those things.  Well, what other toys did you have?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: As far as I can remember that was the biggest thing we got, was a doll every Christmas.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: One time did you mention that your Grandpa Epp used to make you things?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah, he used to make little pine bark wagons with little wheels, you know.  He’d make them out of pine bark and run a little stick through them.  We used to pull those.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I remember him making those for us.  But other than that. . .  We’d take them down to the bank where they would roll, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you ever play in the clay?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We did, I guess, after I got up around 7 or 8 years old.  You know something?  They wouldn’t let us mess with clay because we would put trash in—dirt, you know—and they didn’t, my mama and my grandma neither one, didn’t like no dirty clay!  It was dirt, but no dirt in it!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They wanted clean clay?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So you couldn’t make little toys?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.  We did after we got up a little bigger.  I got up 7 or 8 years old, I made little old things like that.  You know, I remember I made a little cat one time.  I thought that was the cutest little thing!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I can see that little cat yet!  You know how a cat will lay with its little arms folded like this?  I made that little cat, and its tail was curled around its feet, you know, around here.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I made that little cat and I rubbed it, and it burnt solid red!  Yeah, it was solid red!  You know you’ve seen these cats that’s red, you know?  And it looked just like one of those!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I kept that thing for a long, long time.  I don’t know what ever happened to it.  But I did keep that a long time you know.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We used to play with little old things like that.  But I thought that was the prettiest thing!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You should make another one.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I thought about it sometimes.  But I can see that cat yet that I made!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Make me one.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And it wasn’t no more than about that long.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Just a little tiny thing!

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just a little tiny thing.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yeah.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Then we used to make little old chickens, little old ducks, you know, and we played with them after we burned them, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: So they didn’t sell them?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you decorate it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, we didn’t.  They never—we was too small to fool with anything like that then. They wouldn’t let us fool with their tools like that.  Afraid we would leave them out and lose them.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They had a set of tools, and you didn’t play with them like kids do now with things.  Kids play with things that I wouldn’t let mine play with.  But they wouldn’t let us play with that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Of course.  That was serious business.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, because that was something that, if they lost them or threw them away, they’d have to make new ones or, you know, something like that.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well how about rubbing rocks?  Is it hard to find?  Well yours are from where?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Off the Catawba River, down here and around.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Have you ever found your own down there?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  May Blue’s got one of mine I found on the river, and I’ve got to get it from her.  I loaned it to her.  I’ll never get it back if I don’t go over there and get it.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She’ll forget about it.  She keeps telling me, “I still got your rock!”  And if I don’t get it, I’ll die and forget about it!  It came from off the Catawba River, and that’s where mostly my grandmother and them picked theirs up—on the river.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Now, I got a few I got in California when I was out there, and I got some I got in Cherokee  But they’s not right slick yet, you know; I’m just using them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: They’re not as good as the old ones?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well they will be, in time, if I use them a lot.  They’re getting slick now.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well when Martha Jane Harris died what happened with her tools?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Me and my sister divided them.  See, we were the only girls.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: How about your mother’s tools?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well we did the same with hers—we divided them.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s right.  Your mother died first, so you divided hers, and then when Martha Jane—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: We divided hers.  I wish I had her—I don’t know what ever her husband ever done with them, her daughter’s husband.  You see, Gladys had them after Eliza died, and I never tried taking them because that was her mama’s, you know, and she wanted to keep them.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And then, when Gladys died, her husband—he’s a sot, and I don’t know what he’s done with them—probably done throwed them away.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did Gladys make pottery?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She mostly rubbed.  She didn’t make any.  She used to rub for her mother.  She could rub real good!  Oh, she might have made a few little things, but, you know, nothing big or unusual.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Tell me about your mother’s last sickness before she died.  Was she sick a long time?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She was sick about six weeks, I think, before she died.  I was up—I was 20 years old when she died, and I took care of her until she died.  And I just stayed there, right in the house, and kept house for the two boys.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Furman was, ah, I think he was 14 that year, and, of course, Jesse was a lot older.  He was six years older than I am!  He must have been about 27 years old then.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But he was, let’s see—he was working in town, I believe.  He went to work right after she died.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: In the mill?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  He had worked there before.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well what happened to her?  What was wrong with her?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She had kidney trouble.  You know, back then, a lot of things they couldn’t cure, and she died with it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: And so her kidneys just failed?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Just about.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Yes.  Is she buried down in the old cemetery?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Is there anything to tell about her funeral?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, I don’t—I did have the obituary column for her; I guess I got it here somewhere.  I kept it for a long time, and I think I still have it somewhere.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was she like?  Can you tell me any stories about her?  You have told me a little bit about her—how she must have struggled in 1912. . .

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh yeah.  Well she was a hard worker, I’ll tell you that!  Because she—after her husband died, she worked hard.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Like I told you, she worked on the farm, rented the farm out for half to get a, to take care of, so she could raise her family.  And she did that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And, of course, I think she’d make pottery during, some after she’d get through the crop, you know.  And then she’d make a few pieces.  But she worked real hard; she was a hard worker.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: She worked awfully hard!  And she wasn’t an old woman!  She was in her 30s.  But she always said she’d never marry again and put nobody over her children.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And she never did.  But she was young when she died; she wasn’t but 47 years old.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Why did she say that, I wonder?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, you know, most men don’t treat step-children good, and she just felt like no man would be a father to them like their own father would, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Had she seen something like that?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I imagine she had over the years, you know.  A lot of that happens, and I guess she did somewhere along her lifetime.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Where children are mistreated?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: By stepfathers, stepmothers.  And she always said, “I’ll never put nobody over my children.”  And she raised us alone, by herself.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you ever work in the cotton?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You  mean—?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Your mother’s cotton.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  I helped to pick it.  I picked cotton many a time!  And I picked after, well, after mama quit, you know.  The kids all got up big.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I got up a big girl, 16-17 years old; my sister had married; and Jesse was working out, you know.  And there wasn’t nobody home but me and Furman, you know, farming.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And then working as hard as she did, [?] ease up then.  Well, whenever—just like Easter or Fourth of July—I’d go on and want a new dress.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I used to go out and hoe cotton and pick cotton; get paid for it, you know.  Do it for somebody else.  And they’d pay me enough money, and I’d go to the store and buy me enough cloth to make a new dress, something like that.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: That’s how I always got something new for a special occasion: I’d go out and work for it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: For maybe a day or a week?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Oh, for however long it took. . .

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well who did you work for?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I used to pick cotton for Joe Sanders, I remember that.  Joe Sanders used to, you know, raise cotton too.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He had a pretty good farm?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Not too good.  It was a little—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: He was a better carpenter?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  Never was a farmer, but he always tried, you know.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Did you ever see him build a house?  Are there any houses down there that he built?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: No, he always worked off the reservation, you know, for other people.  I guess he built that one he lived in probably.  I don’t know whether he—

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: But it’s gone.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  No.  I won’t say it’s gone either!  Edith Brown lives in it, I think.  I think that’s part of where Joe lived.  Some of it has been redone over.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: I can ask Frances.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, I think that’s part of the house.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That might be it.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  It’s been worked over some, you know; but I remember that’s where Joe lived, right up in there.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s a pretty house site.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It is; it’s pretty.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s a nice house site.  It’s nice, the way you come up there, and it’s on that little hill.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It is.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: That’s a very pretty house site.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I used to work like that a lot.  Anything—if I wanted something new, I’d get out and hoe cotton and pick cotton.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And I used to pick for my uncle, Toad Harris—we called him ‘Toad’ Harris; you know, David Harris.  I don’t know why they called him Uncle Toad.  Because he was short and fat, I think.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Some of our kids named him when he was small—called him Toad.  And they always called him Uncle Toad.  And I worked for him, picked cotton for him.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Was he a good farmer?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: He was pretty good.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Well how much—after they divided up the farms, how much land—

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: They didn’t divide them up.  You just went out and cleared what you wanted.  And if you could use it, that’s the way it was done.  They didn’t put no special—if you went and cleared up a place, it was yours.  You worked it.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: It depended on the energy of the man?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  That’s what it depended on.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Your daddy’s place—how many acres do you reckon your daddy farmed?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I wish I could take you down there some time and let you see.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: We’ll have to go down.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, we can almost get there in the car, we can.  We’d have to walk.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Maybe we should do that Sunday.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Okay.  I went down there with my son, Baby Boy, when he was here at Christmas.  He took me down there.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I hadn’t been down there in a long time, and he wanted to go down there.  And we went down there and rambled around—he had to pull me up the hill up from where we used to carry water from—and fooled around by the branch.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: And he said, “Mama, this [?].”  He said, “I’ll help you.”  He got me up halfway, and he said, “Now rest a while; don’t try to go it all at one time, alright?”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: I did pretty good though.  It’s pretty back in there, but that was always a pretty place down in there where we used to live.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: There used to be some big old trees.  I remember where that house stood, where my dad built that house.  There was, let’s see, there was one, two, three, four great big oak trees.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: You couldn’t reach around them; two people couldn’t reach around them!  One of them is still standing there now.  Big oaks!

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Oh, now isn’t that funny!  I’ve read so many times that there wasn’t enough firewood down there to build a decent fire.  Why would they write those things in The Evening Herald?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Who wrote it?

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Different people.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It wasn’t Indians!  Well where we lived there was plenty of wood.  We had a lot, and we didn’t have to go no distance to get our wood.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You had plenty of firewood.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah, all the firewood we wanted, because back over in there, nobody wanted to live in that place.  It’s off from the road and it’s kind of, “Oh, we don’t want to live over there!”

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But I loved it over there!  And we finally—and I give Nola, Raymond the house place after they got married.  I give Nola a house place down over there; that’s the reason Nola lived down there close to where I was.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: You let her have part of your yard?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: It was kind of a good ways off.  About as far as from here to the chemical place.  Couple hundred yards from where we lived.  I give them a house place, and they built them a house.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Raymond built it?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yeah.  He built a log house first.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: Is that right.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Yes.  Built a log—cut enough logs off and built him a log house, and later he built him a frame house.

text.speaker: TB
text.text_bit: What was the log house like?

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: Well, I believe it was one room, but I believe there wasn’t nobody but him and one child in there.  Just Nola and the one child, Debbie, then that’s the oldest.

text.speaker: GH
text.text_bit: But I give them that land.  So [he] built him a log house and lived in it until he built the other house.
